entry.title: Re: Mass Download of Balance Confirmations
entry.content:
Hello again,

Here's what the expert replied:

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, Customer Balance Confirmation and Supplier Balance Confirmation letters are typically dispatched either physically (hard copy/printed) or electronically via email with an attached PDF document. This can be configured through the output parameter settings by selecting the output channel as either PRINT or EMAIL.

In both cases, users do not need to download the PDF version of the confirmation letters—that is, the system doesn't require or expect users to manually download these documents during normal operations. The PDF download feature remains available but is intended only for rare or special situations, such as when someone needs to review the confirmation for a particular customer or supplier.  A mass download functionality is not supported.

If you require a mass download of Customer or Supplier Balance Confirmation letters, please submit a feature request detailing your specific use case. Alternatively, if your goal is to process the Balance Confirmations further, you could consider requesting additional output channels such as XML or EDI instead of requesting a mass download.

Best regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: UoM changed in Va02 not reflecting in MB51
entry.content:
Updating MSEG entries directly through enhancements is not advisable. These tables are part of SAP’s core inventory accounting and manipulating them artificially will cause serious inconsistencies between logistics, FI/CO, and audit trails.

Instead of trying to force MB51 to show sales order changes, the right approach is to use SD reporting tools (e.g., sales order item reports, document flow, or custom CDS views) to track UoM changes at the order level. MB51 should remain strictly for material movements.

If the business requirement is to see “reserved stock” in the new UoM, build a custom report or Fiori app that reads from the sales order tables (VBAP, VBEP) and shows the reservation quantities in the desired UoM. This way, you meet the reporting need without compromising SAP’s core integrity.

entry.title: Problem with RUM Release Upgrade Management Support
entry.content:
Hello,

I need assistance. I have no communication with support for RUM (Release Upgrade Management). I will describe the issue step by step.

  1. On 18.12.2025, an Upgrade Project request was created with a planned start date of 12.01.2026 and was automatically taken over by SAP for further processing.

  2. The review by SAP was sent very late, only on 13.01.2026, after the planned start date had already passed. The project was returned with the status Customer Managed and IN PLANNING.
    The IN PLANNING status is not correct; it should be IN PREPARATION. Due to this incorrect status and the late response from SAP, we do not have access to the task list, nor are we able to properly fine-tune the timeline.

  3. Since the project was returned to us for further processing significantly late, on 16.01.2026 we set a new start date to 23.01.2026. This was the only change we were able to make because the status is IN PLANNING. After saving the change, I do not see that this update is visible to SAP RUM support. How can we get the project status changed to IN PREPARATION? How should we continue with our work?

I contacted the email address itsm.notification-service@sap.com requesting a correction on the SAP side and a renewed review of the project, as the delayed response from SAP resulted in us missing the originally planned start date. We received a reply stating that technical support can be contacted via this platform, but no further assistance was provided.

Project ID: 2301

Regards,

Andjelka Jankovic

entry.title: SAP BO 4.3 → BO 2025 major upgrade: feasible to handle alone?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
 
I’m looking for a realistic feasibility check, not documentation links.
I’m evaluating a major upgrade from SAP BusinessObjects 4.3 to SAP BusinessObjects 2025 with this setup:
  • BO 4.3 clustered (2 nodes)
  • CMS + Audit DB
  • External Identity Provider / SSO
  • Long-running system with many customizations
  • Some manual, file-level configurations done over the years (Tomcat / security / non-standard tweaks)
I’m not looking for an automatic migration or a 1:1 clone.
What I need to understand before committing is simply this:
 
> Is this realistically manageable by a single experienced BO admin, or is doing this without SAP Consulting / a Partner a serious risk?
 
I’d really value feedback from people who:
  • Have already done major BO upgrades
  • Have dealt with clustered systems, SSO/IdP, or custom configs
  • Can share honest lessons learned (including “don’t do this alone”)

 

Thanks in advance for any real-world advice.

entry.title: Using FileAdapter in SAP HANA SDI for SAP PaPM Cloud
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community! Welcome to this blogpost on how to use FileAdapter in SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI) for SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud integration. 

In our earlier blog on SAP PaPM Cloud Integration with Microsoft Excel, we explored how ExcelAdapter can help business users to bring their Excel file data directly into the SAP PaPM Cloud.

But what happens when your data is not in an Excel file? What if your data is coming in the form of *.csv, *.txt or a tab-delimited file? How can we consume the data in our SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud?

This is where HANA SDI’s FileAdapter comes in.

Before walking through the steps on how to set up FileAdapter for SAP PaPM Cloud Inbound Integration. Here's a quick comparison between FileAdapter and ExcelAdapter:

Comparison

FileAdapter

ExcelAdapter

File Type

*.csv, *.txt, logs

*.xls, *.xlsx

Structure

Delimited (commas, tabs, pipes) 

Tabular, sheet-based

Best For

Raw exports, transactional data

Spreadsheet, planning models

Special Features

Pattern-based reading, real-time replication

Sheet/range selection, metadata handling

Complexity

Requires config file (.cfg) for parsing

More intuitive if you're used to Excel

 

Prerequisites:

  • SAP HANA Data Provisioning Agent is installed and connected to SAP PaPM Cloud. See Data Provisioning Agent Installation and Update Guide and Configuration Guide for SAP HANA Cloud.
  • Register Data Provisioning Adapter for FileAdapter. See Register Data Provisioning Adapters
  • Prepare your source file in a *.csv or *.txt file. Make sure it has headers (column names) and consistent delimiters (commas, tabs or pipes)

Step 1: Create Configuration File in the Data Provisioning Agent

Open a command prompt as Administrator and navigate to <DPAgent_DIR>/agentutils directory. Execute the command to create a configuration file (*.cfg) to tell FileAdapter how to interpret your source file. See Generate the Configuration File with a Command-Line Utility.

createfileformat.bat -file "<CSV folder path>\filename.csv" -firstRowAsColumnName true -cfgdir "<CSV folder path>"

 

Step 2: Prepare Configuration File

The first line in your Configuration File should always include a comment or a description. For further guidance, see File Format Configuration Files

 

Step 3: Configure FileAdapter Preference

Next step is to authenticate the file using AccessToken. To retrieve the AccessToken, open a Command Prompt and enter command: whoami /user. Make sure to record the Security Identifier (SID) as this will be required later in the FileAdapter Preference configuration.

Once we have the SID information, open a Command Prompt as Administrator and go to <DPAgent_Dir>/bin and enter command: agentcli.bat –configAdapters. When prompted, select Option 2 (Set Adapter Preference) then proceed to choose Option 7 (Set FileAdapter Preference). Provide the following information:

Fields

Value

Root Directory

No remote source can reach beyond this directory for data files. This means that you must use this folder/subfolder for remote source configuration

File Format For Root Directory

No remote source can reach beyond this directory for data files. This means that you must use this folder/subfolder for remote source configuration

Access Token

An access token protects the files from access from different agents. Use this password when creating a remote source.

 

Step 4: Set up Remote Source Connection in the SAP HANA Cloud

Go to the HANA Database Explorer of the PaPM Cloud application and set up a Remote Source Connection. Enter the specified values in the corresponding fields.

FIELDS

VALUE

Source Name

Provide source name for the remote connection

Adapter Name

FileAdapter

Source Location

Select the name of the registered DPAgent

Source Option

Local File System

Target Option

Local File System

Root Directory

<CSV Folder Location>

Directory of the file format definitial

<CSV Folder Location>

Use Decryption for Reading

None

Credentials Mode

Technical User

Password

Enter the Security Identifier (SID)

 

Step 5: Map the File to Virtual Table

Create Virtual Table for the file by selecting the remote source connection and locating the corresponding table for the CSV file, and then click Create Virtual Object(s) to generate the Virtual Table.

Create a name for the virtual table and choose the Schema where it will be store, and then, click Create.

 

Open the content of the Virtual Table to see the contents. Note that in the contents additional columns (PATH, NAME, ROWNUMBER, ERROR and PARTITION) are automatically generated.

 

Step 6: Consume in SAP PaPM Cloud

In the SAP PaPM Cloud, you can now proceed to use the virtual table as an input function and your SAP PaPM Cloud can now pull in data directly from the file source.

Standard Model

Refer to Accessing Artifacts from External SAP HANA Cloud Schema to make your schema accessible as an authoring schema in HANA views or table connections in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model.

Universal Model

Refer to Accessing Artifacts from External SAP HANA Cloud Schema to make your schema accessible as an authoring schema in HANA views or table connections in SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model.

Also, for Universal Model, when creating a connection of type “HANA Schema”, you may encounter the following error:

This error happens because the ROWNUMBER field (automatically generated when using FileAdapter) cannot be used as a valid key field in SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model. SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model requires key fields to be either UUID or String type. Since the ROWNUMBER field is of type Integer64, SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model fails to sync.

To successfully activate the Environment when using FileAdapter in SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model, you need to complete the following steps:

1. In the Environment, add a UUIDME field as a characteristic with type UUID

2. Under Connection, replace the Model Field ROWNUMBER to UUIDME. Then, click Apply to save your changes. 

 3. Perform Model Sync and Connection Sync. Then, proceed to activate your environment.

4. Once the environment is activated successfully, you may proceed to check the HANA schema and show the data without any issues.

And that's how you can use FileAdapter in SAP HANA SDI for your SAP PaPM Cloud integration! Thank you for sticking with me on this walkthrough! Try it out in your own environments and let us know how it goes. Share your experiences, tips, or questions in the comments section. Let's keep learning and growing together!

But again even on my machine where it is installed i noticed a feelable improvement with the NoPrinter setting

entry.title: Re: Configuring Multi-Time-Zone Support in SAP SuccessFac...
entry.content:
Hi hyeongeun_lee,

SAP SuccessFactors supports multiple time zones.

The public profile time zone in SuccessFactors comes from the Timezone field in the User Data File (UDF), which in turn comes from the Timezone of the Job info, and that in turn comes from the Location (Foundation Object) of the job info. For more details about this topic, please check this KBA - 2080587 - How to Sync Correct Timezone to Public Profile in Employee Central.

I hope this helps.

Thank you.

Best Regards,

Karen Perez

entry.title: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal
entry.content:
Hi everyone!  

Today, I would like to share with you some impactful insights directly from an SAP Note, which outlines a streamlined approach for sending the events listed in the NF-e Technical Note 2025.002 v1.30, published October 2025. 

You can implement these changes in the outbound invoicing option for Brazil by following the instructions on SAP Note 3692197 and SAP Note 3689265. 

Check out the latest updates and features in our What's New session on the SAP Help Portal: 

  • SAP S/4HANA: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal 
  • SAP ERP: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal 

The Process 

To send these events, you need to create a specific structure, as described in the "Manual da SEFAZ". You should create the new structure through the SEND_GENERIC_EVENT method from the CL_NFE_CLOUD_NFE_PROCESSOR class. This effectively sends the events using the IS_GENERIC_EVENT parameter, which is essential for declaring the structure. 

You have to name this structure as ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_XXXXXX. You replace the XXXXXX for the number of supported events from the NF-e Technical Note 2025.002 v1.30. For example: ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110.  

In this structure, you'll find control fields and event-specific fields that are mapped directly to the XML event. You have to build the DET_EVENTO structure, which can vary depending on the type of event. The field names differ between the backend system and their appearance in the cloud solution. Check the following example:  

The structure of the event 112110 (Informação de efetivo pagamento integral para liberar crédito presumido do adquirente) is denoted as ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. This structure has the following string fields and their equivalent in the cloud solution, following the rules of name conversion: 

  • ATTR_VERSAO -> converted to a__versao to create the XML (you can check the rule to create XML attributes instead of elements in SAP Note 3692197) 
  • DESC_EVENTO -> descEvento 
  • C_ORGAO_AUTOR -> cOrgaoAutor 
  • TP_AUTOR -> tpAutor 
  • VER_APLIC -> verAplic 

Check the XML file obtained after the name conversion. To download the XML file, follow the steps mentioned in SAP Note 3692197.  

<detEvento versao="1"> 
   <descEvento>Informação de efetivo pagamento integral para liberar crédito presumido do adquirente</descEvento> 
   <cOrgaoAutor>35</cOrgaoAutor> 
   <tpAutor>1</tpAutor> 
   <verAplic>1</verAplic> 
   <indQuitacao>1</indQuitacao> 
</detEvento>

DET_EVENTO Structure Declaration 

Create the structure  ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. Ensure the structure matches the following definition: 

TYPES: 
  BEGIN OF ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110, 
    a__versao        TYPE string, " XML Attribute 
    desc_evento      TYPE string, 
    c_orgao_autor    TYPE string, 
    tp_autor         TYPE string, 
    ver_aplic        TYPE string, 
    ind_quitacao     TYPE string, 
  END OF ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110.

Populating DET_EVENTO 

You populate the DET_EVENTO  using assignment based on input parameters of the program. Check the following example: 

DATA : ls_event_112110 TYPE ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. 
ls_event_112110-a__versao = p_ver.         " Version - XML attribute 
ls_event_112110-desc_evento = p_desc.     " Event description 
ls_event_112110-c_orgao_autor = p_orgaut. " Author organization code 
ls_event_112110-tp_autor = p_tpaut.       " Type of authority 
ls_event_112110-ver_aplic = p_verapp.     " Application version 
ls_event_112110-ind_quitacao = p_indqui.  " Settlement indicator

Steps to Send a Generic Event 

Step 1: Declare and Populate IS_GENERIC_EVENT 

The IS_GENERIC_EVENT structure contains high-level control fields required for all types of events, including details such as issuing state, issuer's CNPJ, and access key (P_ACCKEY). Use the following template to populate the structure: 

DATA : ls_generic_event        TYPE nfe_cloud_nfe_map_gnrc_evt. 
ls_generic_event-uuid                = lo_uuid_generator->generate_uuid( ). " Unique identifier 
ls_generic_event-authorize_uuid      = p_authid.                           " Reference UUID 
ls_generic_event-issuing_state       = p_state.                           " State code 
ls_generic_event-environment_type    = 'HOMOLOGATION'.                    " Environment 
ls_generic_event-issuing_type        = 'NORMAL'.                          " Issuing type 
ls_generic_event-issuer_identifier   = p_issuer.                          " Issuer CNPJ 
ls_generic_event-receiver_identifier = '74544297000192'.                " Receiver CNPJ

Step 2: Declare and Populate Specific DET_EVENTO 

Based on the event type (P_TYPE), decide the specific structure for DET_EVENTO. For example: 

If P_TYPE = '112110', use the predefined structure ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110: 

DATA : ls_event_112110 TYPE ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. 
ls_event_112110-a__versao = p_ver.         " Attributes mapped as XML attributes 
ls_event_112110-desc_evento = p_desc. 
ls_event_112110-c_orgao_autor = p_orgaut. 
ls_event_112110-tp_autor = p_tpaut. 
ls_event_112110-ver_aplic = p_verapp. 
ls_event_112110-ind_quitacao = p_indqui. 
ls_generic_event-event_info-det_evento->* = ls_event_112110.  " Assigning DET_EVENTO structure

Step 3: Send the Event 

Invoke the SEND_GENERIC_EVENT method:

TRY. 
  ls_result = lo_processor->send_generic_event( 
      is_generic_event       = ls_generic_event 
      is_company_definition  = ls_company_defition ). 
CATCH cx_nfe_cloud_invalid_value INTO lx_invalid_value. 
  lx_invalid_value->raise_message( ). 
  RETURN. 
ENDTRY.

Checking Event Status 

To verify the status of sent events, follow these steps: 

  1. Service Locator: Use CREATE_SERVICE_LOCATOR_OBJECT from the CL_J_1BNFE_CF_MONITOR class. 
  1. Service Type Parameter: Reference C_SERVICE_EVENT_STATUS from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_CONSTANT. 
  1. Map Events and Generate JSON: Utilize the STRUCTURE_SERIALIZATION method from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_EVENT_UPDATE. 
  1. Client and OA2C Creation: Use SET_REQUEST_JSON and SEND_REQUEST_TO_CLOUD methods from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_SERVICE_COMM. 
  1. Transform JSON Response: Apply GET_RESPONSE_FROM_CLOUD to convert the response into an NF-e format. 
  1. Develop Response Structure: EVENT_TABLE_DESERIALIZATION method helps integrate this into an NF-e structure. 

Building Your Application 

Beyond these steps, you'll need to develop or extend your applications to: 

  • Fill in necessary event data. 
  • Trigger creation and submission based on business processes. 
  • Implement error handling, logging, and monitoring according to your compliance standards. 

That's a wrap for today! I hope this guide serves as a handy reference for anyone navigating the intricacies of sending events in SAP. Stay tuned for more insights and happy coding! 

Until next time,

Natália

SAP e-Invoicing Application Engineer

entry.title: Re: New Jan 2026 "SAP Certified - SAP SuccessFactors Lear...
entry.content:
Hi ElinaBC2025,

Regarding the "AI roleplay" option, it works as follows: Your video and microphone are activated, and an AI-generated photo representing a key customer person (HRO, for example) appears. The AI ​​verbally introduces herself, explaining the test scenario. After that, the questions are spoken by the AI ​​but also appear written on the screen. You must answer them verbally, and as a recommendation, try to provide as much context as possible. For example, if the question is "How many levels are recommended...?", the AI ​​expects you to answer something like "X levels are recommended because..., which impacts..., etc." In other words, share as much knowledge as possible about the topic so that your answer receives a higher score.

Regarding the "recorded video" option, the recommendations above are basically the same: provide as much context as possible, always answering completely. However, in this case, instead of the AI ​​asking the questions and analyzing the answers, we have a video where you will be recorded giving the answers, and this will be evaluated by an expert in the field.

I hope this helps!

Thank you.

Karen Perez

entry.title: Business transformation management: It's time to make it a thing
entry.content:
For several years now, you have been able to visit SAP.com and find a page devoted to Business Transformation Management. The solutions associated with the marketing category/solution area are SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio, and WalkMe, covering enterprise architecture, business process intelligence, and digital adoption, respectively. 

Business transformation management is a a term of relatively recent coinage and, as yet, is not widely used. Search volume for the phrase is low: about 440 searches per month globally, with 90 of those searches originating from the US. Compare this to a more established phrase such as "digital transformation," which boasts seventy-six thousand searches a month. 

In other words, if we can use search volume as a proxy for existence, that is, for "thing-ness," digital transformation would seem to be a thing and business transformation would not. 

But...business transformation IS a thing

I have been working in this solution area since SAP LeanIX was acquired in 2023. For me, business transformation management has been a thing since then. I was already heading in that direction while working at LeanIX where we had, at least since 2021, begun talking about "continuous transformation" as an alternative to digital transformation. 

The idea behind continuous transformation was relatively and in many ways simply an acknowledgement of reality. Digital transformation as a concept had been around, in one form or another, for thirty years or so. By 2021, in the midst of the Covid-19 epidemic, the world had pretty much digitally transformed. With cellphones ubiquitous and most commerce taking place digitally (often by government mandate), talking about digital transformation seemed either anachronistic or redundant. 

And yet, transformations continued across the business landscape. In addition to lingering areas of manual effort in business processes, companies continued to move to the cloud. They continued to acquire and merge with other companies. They continued to introduce new products and services, to expand into new regions, to adopt new operating models. 

The fact of that matter is, as revealed in our just published study–The Capability Mindset: Turning Business Transformation into a Repeatable Discipline–the majority of companies (72%) pursue four or more transformation initiatives annually. In other words, we were not wrong to insist that transformation was continuous. At any given time, your business is transforming, and often in several ways at once. 

That is, when you really look at it, business transformation is a thing. So, why doesn't it feel that way? 

Why business transformation may be hard to see

The study hints at certain reasons people don't yet think of business transformation as a thing. 

For starters, most respondents said they can execute transformations well in individual departments but lack an integrated, enterprise-wide transformation strategy. As evidence of this lack, the study found that only 24% of organizations have a cross-functional transformation governance board and the percentage of organizations that embed transformation goals in senior-leadership KPIs is only slightly higher (25%).

When transformation efforts run in silos and success or failure has little impact on senior leadership, such efforts can be easy to overlook. 

It's not just at the top that companies struggle to make business transformation real and palpable, however. More than half of those surveyed (54%) report challenges with poor communication of transformation vision and benefits. Fifty-three percent struggle to train and up-skill employees to keep pace with transformation.

And, given the continuous nature of transformation and the shortcomings  associated with communication and enablement, it's not surprising that more than half (52%) also struggle with "change fatigue" among employees. 

Finally, data challenges plague many transformation efforts. Fifty-six percent of respondents report poor data quality or inconsistent master data and 55% report the persistence of data silos (mirroring the siloed nature of transformation efforts). Add to this widespread technical debt (55%) and a general absence of roadmaps for technology modernization (only 26% report having modernization roadmaps in place) and you have a perfect storm of poor visibility into both the present and the future. 

So, what is to be done?

Adopt a capability mindset to make transformation a thing

Becoming intentional about your enterprise architecture often begins with business capability mapping . Ontologically speaking, "capabilities," like applications and IT components, are things in the enterprise architecture universe. 

Business capabilities are relatively easy to understand: they are the things your business needs to be able to do. These things include paying employees, marketing your products and services, sourcing and procuring materials, and so on. Knowing what you need to be able to do gives you context for assessing what technology you need as well as evaluating the adequacy and appropriateness of the technology you have. 

As it stands, most companies don't view business transformation as a capability. They tend to view transformations as one-off projects impacting this or that function or line of business. Such a view is mistaken and leads directly to the challenges touched on above. 

The issue is not just that business transformation is continuous, though that alone would be good reason to treat it as a capability worthy of cultivation. Rather, the issue is that every business transformation involves multiple dimensions and changes in these dimensions reverberate throughout the organization.

The study focused on five critical dimensions of transformation: strategy and leadership, data, process, technology and applications, and people and culture. It's not too hard to understand how these dimensions not only influence each other within a particular function but also how they ripple across other functions. 

Consider a reorganization of your sales function. Obviously, this directly involves the sellers and their managers. But it will also impact the marketing organization by creating new ways of generating and managing pipeline. This will, in turn, impact processes, technology, and data processing in marketing. It will also impact HR, who will have to begin recruiting to support the new model as well as revise org charts and performance review processes, as well as finance, who will have to ensure that new compensation models get reflected in payroll. 

Frankly, there are probably more impacts that I haven't mentioned. But, you get the picture and the bottom line is this: the only way to manage and execute business transformation well is to acknowledge its continuous nature and view it holistically. That is, you must think of it as a capability alongside human resource management, finance management, supply chain management, and all the other capabilities that make up a functioning, successful business.

There are levels to this stuff

Once you accept that business transformation management is a thing, specifically, a necessary and powerful business capability, you can begin investing in building and improving this capability in a methodical, systematic way.

As with any capability, of course, there are levels of maturity. Some companies have created a robust business transformation management capability. Others have only just embarked on their journey. Our study found that only 6% of companies can be considered "Leaders" in this area. These companies are more likely to report close alignment between business needs and technology capabilities. They are also more likely to see the value in involving employees early in the transformation process as well as in having a dedicated change management and training function. 

Interestingly, as companies move up the maturity curve, they become less concerned with things like data-driven decision-making and continuous process improvement, goals that are top of mind for Beginners. Those are challenges they have already solved, making them part of their standard operating model. Instead, Leaders focus much more on building a culture that enables people and creates strategic accountability.

Business transformation's moment has arrived

I encourage you to read the study. It contains a lot of insight into the state of business transformation management today, where companies struggle the most, and how Leaders differentiate themselves from everyone else. 

But, more importantly, I urge to you take business transformation management seriously for the sake of you and your business. I do so because we now face the greatest driver of transformation for the foreseeable future: AI. Not only is AI transforming businesses at every level, but being able to capitalize on the power of this technology itself demands business transformation, beginning with the transformation of your company's data landscape.

Given the massive changes that AI brings with it, it's safe to say that business transformation management isn't just one more business capability among many, but the critical business capability going forward. 

Since only 6% of companies have already developed such a capability, it's time for everyone else to start catching up.

entry.title: Re: MANAGE SERVICE QUOTATION
entry.content:
Manage Sales Quotations is designed for product‑centric sales (materials, goods). Uses SD sales documents (quotation → sales order → delivery → billing). Item categories are determined based on material type, sales document type, and sales area. Focus is on logistics execution (availability check, delivery scheduling, shipping).

Manage Service Quotations is designed for service‑centric sales (consulting, maintenance, professional services). Integrates with Service Management and Service Orders rather than logistics. Supports service‑specific attributes like:

  • Service duration, effort, resource assignment.
  • Service contract linkage.
  • Service‑related billing (time & material, fixed price).

The key differences is

  • Sales Quotation → leads to a Sales Order (logistics).
  • Service Quotation → leads to a Service Order/Contract (service execution).

They serve different downstream processes.

The errors you encountered is because, the system could not map your service material to a valid item category in the service quotation document type. In Public Cloud, item category determination is pre‑configured and not freely editable like on‑premise. If you used a generic service material without proper material group/service category, the system cannot find the right item category. Ensure the material type is SERV (service material). Check that the document type for service quotation is correctly assigned to service item categories in CBC configuration. Use the delivered service quotation item categories (e.g., SRV1, SRV2 depending on scope).

entry.title: ODBC connection to SAP HANA HDI container fails with service key credentials
entry.content:
Hello SAP Support,

We are facing an issue when connecting from SQL Server to an SAP HANA HDI container using ODBC and a linked server.

Context:

  • Global Account A

  • SAP HANA version: 2025.28.17

  • Connection type: SQL Server linked server via ODBC

  • Target: SAP HANA HDI container

Observed behavior:

  • ODBC connection test is successful.

  • Direct connection to the SAP HANA instance using admin credentials works.

  • Connection using the credentials from the HDI container service key fails (authentication/connection error).

  • Same configuration works correctly in another Global Account B running SAP HANA version 2025.28.18, where HDI service key credentials allow a successful connection.

This suggests a difference in behavior or configuration between the two HANA versions or Global Accounts.

What we have verified:

  • Service key is correctly generated from the HDI container.

  • Credentials, host, port, and schema parameters are correctly mapped in the ODBC configuration.

  • Network and firewall settings are identical between both environments.

  • SQL Server and ODBC driver versions are the same.

Request:
Please help identify:

  • Whether there is a known issue or behavioral change in SAP HANA 2025.28.17 regarding external ODBC access to HDI containers.

  • Any required privileges, roles, or additional configuration needed to allow ODBC connections using HDI service key credentials.

  • Differences in HDI or security handling between versions 2025.28.17 and 2025.28.18.

We can provide:

  • Exact error messages returned by SQL Server / ODBC :  “Unable to initialize the data source object of OLE DB provider ‘MSDASQL’ for linked server ‘SAPHANAXXX’.
    The OLE DB provider ‘MSDASQL’ for linked server ‘SAPHANAXXX’ returned the message ‘[Microsoft][ODBC Driver Manager] SQLSetConnectAttr failed’.
    The OLE DB provider ‘MSDASQL’ for linked server ‘SAPHANAXXX’ returned the message ‘[SAP AG][LIBODBCHDB DLL][HDBODBC] General error;10 authentication failed: Detailed info for this error can be found with correlation ID ‘309CF299E44F1E42B45059181AC408FA’’.
    (.Net SqlClient Data Provider)”

Looking forward to your guidance.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Different cost centers visible in customer invoice po...
entry.content:
How Cost Center derivation works in FI postings when FB01 is executed, you can enter a cost center on the line item. However, the system does not always keep that exact cost center in reporting. Instead, it applies account assignment logic based on the G/L account, controlling settings, and substitution rules.

FBL5N shows line items from BSID/BSAD (customer open/cleared items). The cost center displayed there is not taken directly from what you typed in FB01, but from the CO object assignment that results after FI → CO integration. If the G/L account is defined as “cost element,” the system derives the controlling object (cost center, profit center, internal order) according to customizing.

Why Cost Center may differ is because

  • Automatic derivation rules: Profit center derivation, substitution exits, or validation rules may overwrite what you entered.
  • Default account assignment: If the G/L account has a default cost center/profit center in OKB9, that takes precedence.
  • Revenue postings: For customer invoices, the system often derives the profit center from the material/customer master, and the cost center may be replaced by the reconciliation logic.
  • Integration with CO: If the posting is revenue‑related, the system may not allow a direct cost center assignment at all, and instead assigns based on configuration.

To check the actual derivation perform the below steps

  • Line item display (FB03): Open the accounting document and check the CO assignment in the line item.
  • Document splitting / substitution rules: Review if substitutions are active in transaction OBBH.
  • Default account assignment (OKB9): See if the G/L account has a default cost center/profit center.
  • Cost element category (KA03): Check if the G/L account is a primary cost element and how it integrates with CO.

entry.title: SAP BTP - APIM - How to Master Custom Monitoring in case of API-Mega-Proxy
entry.content:
Introduction

In the previous blog  SAP BTP - APIM - Demystified: Designing a Single API Proxy with Dynamic Routing for Multiple Targets where I explained the way where one API Proxy endpoint can routing the messages for mutiple targets endpoins, in this case Iflows in SAP CPI for one specific package.

I could not present a clear view how to monitoring those messages clearly in the dashboard, so the intention of this blog is present how to create the custom dimension, how to setup the statistic collector policies and the result in the custom dashboard SAP APIM.

However, centralizing traffic often creates a visibility vacuum. This point was raised by @MateuszPiotrowski , I didn't add in previous blog because was too large already.

The "Invisible Traffic" - Challenge MegaProxy

When some of distinct business processes (iFlows) share a single API Proxy from the same CPI Package, standard analytics become a "black box." In the default dashboard, all traffic appears under the same Proxy name. 

In this post, we will bridge this gap. I will demonstrate how to implement Granular Observability by extracting technical metadata and transforming it into human-readable business dimensions. Using JavaScript and the Statistics Collector policy, we will "unmask" the Mega-Proxy traffic, providing full transparency directly within the SAP APIM Analytics Dashboard.

The integration prespective below:

Figure 1 - Integration Prespective

The Strategy: Mapping Business Identity

Observability in SAP APIM doesn’t happen by accident; it is engineered. To solve the "visibility vacuum," we must capture the iFlow’s identity the moment the request hits the Proxy.

API MegaProxy - ProxyEndpoint routing:

Figure 2 - Routing based on proxy.pathsuffix

Target Endpoints:

Figure 3 - One API Proxy and mutiples Targets Endpoint.

The JavaScript Logic: The Metadata Translator

Instead of manual mapping, we utilize a centralized JavaScript policy in the PreFlow. This script acts as our "Metadata Translator": it inspects the proxy.pathsuffix (the incoming URL) and injects meaningful business context into flow variables.

Than in each of target endpoint you need to add the java script below plus the policy Statistic Collector.

function setCustomHeaders(){
    var path = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
    var packageName = "sap.scn.package";
    var iflowName = "Unknown Iflow";
    
    // Lógica de mapeamento dinâmico
    if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/methoddelete") > -1) {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodDelete";
    } 
    else if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/methodget") > -1) {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodGet";
    } 
    else if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/methodpost") > -1) {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodPost";
    }
    else if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/methodput") > -1) {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodPut";
    }
    // Create variables
    context.setVariable("custom.package_name", packageName);
    context.setVariable("custom.iflow_name", iflowName);
}

Custom Metrics Setup:

Recorded data is only useful if it can be visualized. You must prepare the ground in the Analytics portal before the policy can successfully register data:

  • Navigate to Analyze > Settings > Custom Metrics/Dimensions.
  • Add a new dimension named sapcpiIflow.
  • Expert Insight: SAP will prefix these fields as custom_sapcpiIflow. This is the exact name you will reference in your policy and search for in your reports.

Figure 4 - Create the dimension custom to be used in the Policy

Policy Statistic Collector:

As you can see in the tag Statistic reffering to custom_sapcpiIflow with the reference of custom.iflow_name created by the javascript above as sample.

<Statistic name='custom_sapcpiIflow' ref='custom.iflow_name' type='string'>0</Statistic>

<!--Specify Stats collector policy to add custom dimensions and measures --><StatisticsCollector xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt" async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true">
  <Statistics>
<!-- prepopulated template -->
<!-- Uncomment Statistic which needs to be collected and define reference variable-->
    <Statistic name='custom_sapcpiIflow' ref='custom.iflow_name' type='string'>0</Statistic>
</Statistics>
</StatisticsCollector>

Add in seguency:

Figure 4 - Those policies should be addded in all targetEndpoint PRE-FLOW

The Result:

Once this configuration is live, you move from a generic chart to a Business Dashboard. You can now generate

  • Volume Tracking: Exactly how many calls are being processed by iFlow A vs. iFlow B or C?
  • Targeted Performance: Which specific iFlow endpoint is experiencing high latency?
  • Error Granularity: Which iFlow is generating the most errors? Instead of seeing "Proxy Errors," you can pinpoint which specific backend integration is failing

Image - 5 - Custom Dashboard monitoring SAP APIM

Image 6 - CPI Iflows

Conclusion:

Mastering the Mega-Proxy was just the beginning. By implementing Observability, you transform a simple integration into a strategic asset. You now provide total transparency for stakeholders what is running over one API Proxy endpoint and absolute control and visibility of the traffic and operations.

Kind regards,

Viana.

entry.title: Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud test, demo and development service
entry.content:
If you’re an SAP Partner thinking about where data, applications, and AI truly come together, this session is for you.

We’re hosting a webinar on Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud test, demo and development service, and it’s designed to give partners a clear, practical view of what’s coming—and how to get hands-on quickly.

We’ll walk through how SAP Business Data Cloud fits into SAP’s overall product strategy, then get very concrete: how to order the new test, demo, and development service via SAP for Me and SAP Store, what’s included in the initial release (available from November 2025), and what’s planned for early 2026.

The thing is capacity-based pricing can feel abstract.  So, we’ll break it down, honestly, with guidance on estimating capacity units for real partner scenarios.

Plus, we’ll explore how partners can build analytical and AI-enriched apps on SAP Business Data Cloud and even commercialize them via SAP Store.  We’ll also cover alternative options like the 30-day free trial and SAP Demo Environment 2.0.

entry.title: Use REST services in Graph
entry.content:
Hello!

In this part of the tutorial on Graph we will focus on the support of REST services in Graph. For an overview of other parts of this series, check out the Information Map.

REST support in Graph

Graph enables the use of REST services as data sources for business data graphs (BDGs). Compared to OData data sources, there are some key differences:

  • The metadata that describes the service must be provided separately along with the service endpoint in the OpenAPI format.
  • OpenAPI does not have the concept of entities like OData does. Instead, it focuses on operations, which are represented as actions and functions in a BDG.

We will now explain how these differences are being handled by Graph in more detail:

Metadata for a REST service

REST services are commonly described using the OpenAPI format, which outlines the operations and resources available in the service. Unlike OData, which provides a $metadata endpoint for accessing service metadata, plain REST services do not have a standard way to access this information. Since Graph requires metadata to work with REST services, users must provide this metadata when setting up a business data graph.

Graph uses BTP destinations to define access to data sources. To use a REST service as data source, users need to create 2 destinations:

  • a data destination: that points to the actual REST service
  • a metadata destination: where the OpenAPI metadata document for the REST service can be retrieved

Both destinations also need annotations that connect them together, so that Graph can understand which metadata destination belongs to which REST service destination.

Data Model

Graph exposes a unified API endpoint for the OData and GraphQL protocols. Both offer an entity (or type/object) model in which data can be represented. Plain REST as described by OpenAPI does not have a strict entity model, and services are defined as different operations. For example, an operation might be to 'find a pet by name' or 'retrieve pets of a store' in a pet-store service. However, to expose these REST-operations as valid OData in the unified API, Graph transforms them into unbound OData operations (actions & functions) in the BDG. We refer to these also as mirrored operations, similar to mirrored entities. As part of that transformation, some changes are made to the signature of the operations to align with the OData standard. These include:

  • all paths are flattened: for example a GET /users/pets is transformed to a GET users_pets in the BDG
  • all methods are standardized to GET and POST, with the underlying method being appended to the operation name: for example a DELETE /users/pets becomes a POST /users_pets__delete

Example

Having explained the main concepts of REST support in Graph, let's now look at a practical example. We will take the try-out sandbox of this SAP Ariba Network Catalog Management REST service and use it in a BDG. You can also download the OpenAPI metadata document for the service there under API Resources / API specification.

Tutorial Setup

Before we can use the SAP Ariba service in a BDG, we need to setup the two destinations in SAP BTP.

Prerequisites:

  • SAP Integration Suite with API Management and Graph enabled
  • Access to destinations and service instances in SAP BTP cockpit

Data Destination

Open the SAP BTP Cockpit and create a new destination from scratch in the BTP subaccount where you have Graph and SAP Integration Suite. Enter the following details

  • Name: ariba-network-catalog-mgmt
  • URL: https://sandbox.api.sap.com/ariba/api/network-catalog-mgmt/v1/sandbox

Also add these two additional properties to the destination:

  • Key: Graph.destinationType with the value: REST. This declares this destination as a REST data destination to Graph.
  • Key: URL.headers.apiKey with the value: <your sandbox API key> to add your sandbox API key for authentication purposes (this only applies to this sandbox-example). You can retrieve your API key here: https://api.sap.com/settings.

data destination in BTP cockpit

Metadata Destination

Next, we need to define the metadata destination that points to a location where Graph can access the OpenAPI metadata document. This could be done in a number of ways by hosting this file in a file-server/document storage or at a custom service endpoint for example. For sake of keeping this tutorial simple we will only use SAP Integration Suite to make this file available to Graph: we will create an API artifact which returns the content of the OpenAPI metadata file and then create the metadata destination that points towards the endpoint of that API artifact. Note that this is only for the purposes of this tutorial, and not a requirement.

Hosting the OpenAPI file with an API artifact (optional, only for the tutorial)

First we create the API artifact in SAP Integration Suite. Open Integration Suite and go to Design > Integrations and APIs. Choose an existing package or create a new one. In the package click Edit and open the Artifacts tab. Now you can select Add > API in the table menu. Follow the API creation dialog and select REST API as API Type, Create as Method and then give it the following name: Ariba-Network-Catalog-OpenAPI. Open the created API and in the 'Handle Request' lane select the 'Content Modifier' step. In the bottom UI panel you will then see the Message Body tab where we can paste a constant body this API should return. Here, we will paste the JSON content of the OpenAPI specification of the service (available here). If you have other APIs in the tenant you might also want to assign a unique path for this API. To do that select the HTTPS arrow outgoing from the Start participant, and then in the bottom UI panel you can edit the 'Connection' and change the path in the 'Address' field. Here, we are using /ariba-network-catalog-openapi. Then save the API artifact and deploy it. You can check the deployment status under Monitor > Integrations and APIs > Manage Integration Content: All. When it is deployed, the OpenAPI document will be available at that endpoint. Copy the endpoint URL for later.

constant message body returns the OPenAPI spec JSON

 

unique path for this API artifact

 

monitoring view of the deployed API artifact, with the endpoint URL

To access that endpoint in a destination, we also need the authentication details. Here, we want to authenticate using OAuth client credentials that we obtain from a SAP Process Integration Runtime. For that, go to BTP Cockpit and under Services > Instances and Subscriptions you can find it or create a new one. Then create a Service Key for that instance. We now have a set of client credentials we need for authentication: namely the clientid, clientsecret and tokenurl.

process integration runtime with a service key in BTP cockpit 

Creating the Destination

Now we can create the Metadata destination. Enter the following details:

  • Name: ariba-network-catalog-mgmt-openapi
  • URL: the API artifact endpoint URL from above
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • Client ID: clientid from above
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from above
  • Token Service URL: tokenurl from above

We will also annotate this destination with additional properties, to tell Graph that this is the metadata destination for the previously created ariba-network-catalog-mgmt destination:

  • Key: Graph.destinationType, with a value of OpenAPI
  • Key: Graph.metadataFor, with a value of ariba-network-catalog-mgmt

metadata destination

Now the destination setup is complete and we can create a BDG.

Creating the BDG with REST data sources

With the data destination and the metadata destination created, we can now continue to create a BDG with the REST service. The process does not differ much in this case. In Integration Suite under Design > Graph, create a new Business Data Graph with the ID rest-bdg. In the list of destinations, you can now see an ariba-network-catalog-mgmt entry with the type REST. The info icon shows you more details, for example that Graph has identified which metadata destination belongs to this entry. Just select the entry and continue. When the dialog is finished and we see a preview of the BDG details, we can also change the namespace of the data source from my.custom to my.ariba (this is optional). Continue by activating the BDG.

data source selection when creating a new BDG

 

editing the namespace of a data source

 

overview of the activated BDG

Making Queries against the BDG

With the BDG activated, we can now inspect the mirrored operations. Open the BDG in Developer Hub (there is a link on the overview tab of the BDG). You will see the following operations:

  • GET products (mirrored from GET /products)
  • GET products_ (mirrored from GET /products/{productid})
  • POST products__delete (mirrored from DELETE /products/{productid})
  • POST products__patch (mirrored from PATCH /products/{productid})
  • POST products_post (mirrored from POST /products)

The productid path parameter here is either transformed into an unbound function path parameter, or an unbound action body parameter in this example. This illustrates the transformation that Graph makes of the mirrored operations into valid OData operations as mentioned earlier. In the try out tab we can see all the parameters of the operation and also give it a go.

Note: Graph treats all parameters of mirrored operations as required at this time. However, you can set the value to null.

 
This SAP Ariba sandbox API requires an X_ARIBA_NETWORK_ID parameter. You can use the value AN02005777309 for this sandbox. When running the my.ariba/products operation, we can see that we get the response from the REST service in a valid OData format.
 
trying out the mirrored functions in Developer Hub (Graph Navigator)

Summary

In this tutorial we had a look at how REST services can be used as data sources in a business data graph. With this feature, you can integrate data from REST services alongside data from OData services into a single unified Graph API.

You can learn more about REST-support in Graph in the documentation:

  • REST services as data sources
  • Connect to your business systems: REST services

--

Florian Moritz

entry.content:
@Abuislam1 

Yes is also possible via query or header you just need to change the routing parameters.

Query:

variable: request.querystring  -  sample: Client_id=100&Receiver_ID=SAPCLNT200&Sender_ID=343132143
 
In case that you want make based on custom headers in the message you need create something like this:
 
Custom headers Postman:

 

 

Java Script to capture the custom headers based on the name, without it you don't have visibility of the variable in runtime:
 

 

//Custom Headers
function getcustomheaders(){
    var businessUnit = context.getVariable("request.header.X-Business-Unit");
    var sourceSystem = context.getVariable("request.header.X-Source-System");
    context.setVariable("custom.business_unit", businessUnit);
    context.setVariable("custom.source_system", sourceSystem);
}

 

Really no sure if it's really valid routing based on the header but anyway the solution is in place.

entry.title: Accounting Evolves, Digital Transforms. With IPSAS.
entry.content:
Why IPSAS and Digital Transformation Matter for Public Sector

Public sector organizations worldwide face a dual challenge: adopting International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS) while driving digital transformation. This isn’t just about technology—it’s about teamwork, governance, and collaboration.

IPSAS adoption ensures transparency and accountability in financial reporting. Digital transformation, powered by platforms like SAP Business Suite, accelerates this process by automating workflows, enabling real-time insights, and embedding AI-driven intelligence.

IPSAS Meets the Digital Era
The December 2025 Brussels event, Where IPSAS Meets Digital Transformation, brought together leaders from EU institutions, EY, SAP, and ServiceNow to explore how digital technologies are reshaping public‑sector financial management. Speakers highlighted that European institutions are operating in an increasingly volatile landscape, characterized by geopolitical uncertainty, legacy systems, and rising regulatory complexity. IPSAS continues to act as the backbone of trustworthy public reporting, but the message was clear: only by coupling IPSAS with modern digital tools—AI‑enabled ERP, integrated risk platforms, and automated workflows—can institutions meet the transparency and efficiency demands of tomorrow.

SUMMA: A Once‑in‑a‑Generation Transformation
A good intro on modernization of an accounting platform was  the European Commission’s SUMMA program, its next‑generation financial management platform set to replace ABAC. SUMMA aims to create standardized, automated, and analytics‑ready processes across budgeting, accounting, treasury, and reporting. Presenters emphasized the enormous scale: 450,000 beneficiaries, over 2.5 million payments per year, and more than 13,000 users. The transition faces challenges such as aligning diverse processes with standard solutions, overcoming resistance to change, and integrating dozens of corporate and local systems. Yet with a disciplined “greenfield” approach, iterative pilots, strong governance, and SAP partnership, SUMMA is positioned to become the digital heart of EU financial operations.

Innovation Through AI, Integrated Toolchains, and Process Excellence
Jointly with  EY we showcased how an integrated digital toolchain—SAP Business Suite with embedded AI, SAP Signavio for process intelligence, and WalkMe for adoption—can modernize IPSAS‑aligned financial processes. Demonstrations highlighted low‑touch accounting, AI‑assisted controls, automated budget insights, and end‑to‑end process standardization. Signavio enables IPSAS‑compliant workflows with embedded checkpoints, while WalkMe accelerates user adoption through in‑app guidance and automation. Together, these tools strengthen data accuracy, improve compliance, and support continuous transformation—critical pillars as public‑sector finance embraces AI and new digital operating models.
See below the new reference content in LeanIX for Public Sector transformation projects:

What is IPSAS 47 & 48? New Standards, New Challenges
The closing sessions addressed the upcoming IPSAS 47 (Revenue) and IPSAS 48 (Transfer Expenses), which take effect in January 2026 and introduce more nuanced accounting models built around the concept of “binding arrangements.” Speakers examined practical challenges such as identifying enforceable rights and obligations, defining compliance obligations, assessing transfer rights, and managing new reporting requirements. While these standards increase complexity, they also strengthen accountability, aligning public‑sector reporting more closely with economic reality. Panelists agreed: effective implementation will require robust governance, high‑quality data, strong systems alignment, and significant education for both preparers and stakeholders.

The Road Ahead
Digital transformation and IPSAS adoption are not isolated initiatives—they are strategic imperatives for modern governance. With SAP’s integrated solutions and AI-driven innovation, governments can achieve transparency, efficiency, and sustainability.

entry.title: Inside the GCID AI Hackathon: A Global Contest where AI Initiatives came to life.
entry.content:
A journey that came to life on stage

The Hackathon had place in December 10 during a hybrid event hosted by Matheus Souza, AI Incubation Head, in Sofia. Where a global audience came together both in person and online. And more than 170 participants tuned in as the 11 finalist teams presented their work during the qualifying round and later to the finals.

Each team stepped on stage with a short, high-impact pitch supported by a live demo. In just 7 minutes, they told the story behind their solutions, showing how AI can address concrete technical and business challenges when creativity, and clear communication come together. From this round, three teams stood out and advanced to the final.

The final round opened with motivating messages from Ozren Kopajtic, GCID Head, Kiril Krantev representing the GCID T&I Cloud Operations, and Ricardo Silva GCID Business Delivery Excellence Head. Then the atmosphere was further energized by an inspiring message from Thomas Saueressig, and the executive jury: Radoslav Nikolov, Niraj Singh, Boris Maeck, Henning Heitkötter, and Ricardo Silva. Who encouraged teams to continue pushing their ideas.

Awarding outstanding ideas and execution

Throughout the hackathon, one message became clear: AI has the potential to reshape how we operate, decide, and scale across the organization. The event came an end with Radoslav, Ricardo and Matheus, announcing and celebrating the teams whose solutions stood out for their originality, technical strength, and real-world applicability:

  • First place:" AI-Powered AWX Analyser & Hammer Helper" by Barath Ramachandran, Suresh Kumar Sekar, and team
  • Second place: "Smart Data Center" by Geghard Bedrosian, Philipp Matthes, and team
  • Third place: "AI for Smarter Observability Hygiene" by Mario Romero, Duc Nguyen, and team

What’s next for the hackathon journey

Rather than an ending, this first edition marked the beginning of something bigger. Announced at the end of the event, the hosting city for this year's edition of the GCID AI Hackathon will take is Budapest. There the community is set to continue growing and creating even more space for experimentation and innovation.

For those who couldn’t attend, or want to experience it again, you can watch the recordings of the event and relive the amazing presentations of the teams here:

  • Round 1
  • Round 2

The excitement is already building for what the next edition will bring, and we can't wait for it to begin. See you there?

entry.title: Distance determination in a Freight Order with Basic TM
entry.content:
